Award.AwardTitle: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: Citizen Science Assists a Novel Measurement of Mass-Loss Rates and Extends the Galactic Census of Runaway Massive Stars
Award.AbstractNarration:
Stars with masses much greater than that of our Sun are the engines that drive the evolution of our galaxy, mixing the interstellar gas and dust with their winds, radiation, and eventually their violent deaths in supernova explosions. The rate at which these massive stars lose matter is an important quantity in determining how these stars evolve near the ends of their lives. There are, however, large uncertainties in the measurements of mass-loss rate for these stars with major discrepancies between theoretical and observational results. The goal of this project is to measure mass loss from massive stars through a unique program that involves "citizen science" called Zooniverse.

This project will use the Zooniverse citizen science program to enable thousands of non-scientists to comb through recently completed Spitzer and WISE space telescope surveys in search of bow shock nebulae. These bow shock nebulae are indicative of runaway massive stars ejected from their stellar birthplaces. It is expected that the citizen scientists will identify approximately 300 massive stars through their bow shock structure. These identifications will be followed up by spectroscopic measurements with the 2.3m Wyoming Infrared Observatory (WIRO) in order to derive mass-loss rates, which will result in a statistically compelling sample of objects for comparison with theoretical models.

Both PIs are heavily involved in the education and training of graduate and undergraduate students, and the proposed work will further strengthen the students' exposure to astronomical research. The observations with WIRO telescope will foster mutually beneficial exchanges between the urban, predominantly Hispanic undergraduate institution Cal Poly Pomona and the rural University of Wyoming through hands-on observational astronomy and data analysis. The Cal Poly Pomona proposal in this collaboration is a Research in Undergraduate Institutions (RUI) project, which will offer numerous opportunities to train new scientists with a strong emphasis on recruiting students from underrepresented groups into STEM fields. This project will also initiate a Research Experience for Teachers (RET) program at WIRO that will pair secondary science teachers with University of Wyoming faculty and summer Research Experience for Undergraduate (REU) program students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our collaboration of over 20 undergraduate and graduate students at the University of Wyoming and the Cal Poly Pomona State University has used images from NASA's Spitzer Space Telescope and Wide-Field Infrared Explorer to discover nearly 1000 new "bowshock" nebulae created by stars as they move at high speeds through interstellar space.  These discoveries show that bowshock nebulae are much more common than previously thought and increase by more than a factor of ten the number of such nebulae that are known. Our surprising initial discoveries were featured by no fewer than 20 online news outlets following our press release at the 2017 January meeting of the American Astronomical Society where we announced that our Milky Way Galaxy appears to be swarming with these nebulae. 

Our team used telescopes at the Wyoming Infrared Observatory and the Apache Point Observatory to show that at least 95% of these nebulae are powered by O- and B-type stars, the hottest and most massive stars in the universe.  Contrary to expectations when we began this work, not all of the stars have high speeds greater than about 25 kilometers per second.  Most have modest space velocities of 5-10 kilometers per second.

Each of these stars emits a wind of charged particles (protons and electrons) much like our sun does but thousands to millions of times stronger.  In our sun the wind is responsible for creating aurorae in the atmosphere of Earth during solar storms.  In other stars this wind is responsible for creating the infrared bowshock nebulae detectable even at vast distances across the Milky Way.  The shape and size of the nebula, along with the speed of the star, lets us measure the rate at which the star is losing mass in this wind.  We find that massive stars lose mass less rapidly than had been previously determined in other studies by about a factor of three.  This revised finding has serious implications for the life cycle of massive stars. Most massive stars undergo supernova explosions when their nuclear fuel is exhuasted.  They leave behind a collapsed dense core known as a neutron star or, if the star's core is quite massive at the time of explosions, a black hole.  Our finding of lower mass loss implies that nature creates more black holes and fewer neutron stars.  It may also change the number of observable supernovae in the universe and alter the amount of heavy elements like oxygen and silicon that these stars produce. Our findings also have implications for the number of merging neutron star or black hole binary systems that will be discovered with gravitational wave experiments.  

Our research program recruited thousands of citizens from around the world in helping to identify the nebulae.  The online platform known as the Milky Way Project, part of the zooniverse.org, enabled interested citizens help identify new bowshock nebulae by combing through thousands of NASA satellite images.  Our work also provided young scientists at both universities with paid internship opportunities to practice doing real science as they obtained their bachelors degrees. Our project also provided training for one PhD student who, along with the undergraduates, recevied advanced instruction in remote imaging, digital data analysis, scientific programming, astrophysics, and science communication.  We have thereby strengthened the scientific and technological workforce in the U.S. as we raise up the next generation of scientists and engineers.
